bibl.title: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Laura Armistead Carter, October 1, 1923

div1.p: Russell writes that he will send letters to Laura Carter for her father's consideration, but emphasizes that she should not allow him to overwork.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Laura Armistead Carter, October 1, 1923
div1.opener:

INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD

THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
61 BROADWAY, NEW YORK
CABLE ADDRESS “INTERCOM”
October 1, 1923.
My dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
Your letters of September 26 and 28 arrived promptly, and
I am very much relieved to know that your father's condition is so much
better, and that you plan to go to Baltimore as soon as the situation
is favorable.

As you have indicated that it is all right for us to continue
to send on letters for your father's consideration in your care, we shall
do so, and I know that we can trust your judgment as to whether or not it
is well to bother him with the items. I, personally, am inclined to think
that you should go very slowly in letting him work. It takes energy and
there is more or less excitement about it. Therefore, I hope that you
will think a good many times about it before you show your father any
letters, or bring any real yellow fever business to his attention. Later,
however, when he is in Baltimore and in better physical condition, you
can let us know. I shall, of course, stop to see him at the first
opportunity.
Please give him my best wishes, and believe me
div1.closer:
Yours very sincerely, F. F. Russell Miss Laura A. Carter,
Badin Hospital,
Badin, North Carolina.
